Name: Painted jar
Description: Pottery ovoid jar with rounded base, convex profile and slightly spreading mouth. Covered with a creamy slip, and painted with bands in black and red, and a red-background petal motif around the neck. Painted pottery was never common in Egypt, but became more widespread during the height of Empire in the late 18th Dynasty. This example was acquired near Hierakonpolis, and may be from a burial of that date there.
